title: Rnaseq (with probes) dataset template schema
description: Rnaseq (with probes) dataset template schema generated by the CEDAR Template Editor 2.7.1

propertyDescriptions.lab_id: A locally assigned identifier provided by the data provider for the dataset. It is used to reference an external metadata record that may be maintained independently, enabling traceability and supporting provenance tracking. Example: Visium_9OLC_A4_S1.
propertyDescriptions.analyte_class: The analyte class which is the target molecule that the assay is measuring. Example: DNA.
propertyDescriptions.acquisition_instrument_vendor: The company that manufactures or supplies the acquisition instrument. An acquisition instrument is a device equipped with signal detection hardware and signal processing software. It captures signals produced by assays, such as variations in light intensity or color, or signals corresponding to molecular mass. If the instrument was custom-built or developed internally, enter "In-House". Example: Illumina.
propertyDescriptions.acquisition_instrument_model: The specific model of the acquisition instrument, as manufacturers often offer various versions with differing features or sensitivities. These differences may be relevant to the processing or interpretation of the data. If the instrument was custom-built or developed internally, enter "In-House". If the model is unknown, enter "Unknown". Example: HiSeq 4000.
propertyDescriptions.source_storage_duration_value: The length of time the sample was stored prior to processing it. For assays performed on tissue sections, this refers to how long the tissue section (e.g., slide) was stored before the assay began (e.g., imaging). For assays performed on suspensions, such as sequencing, it refers to how long the suspension was stored before library construction started. Example: 12.
propertyDescriptions.source_storage_duration_unit: The unit of measurement used to specify the source storage duration value. Example: hour.
propertyDescriptions.time_since_acquisition_instrument_calibr: The length of time since the acquisition instrument was last serviced or calibrated. This provides a metric for assessing drift in data capture. Example: 10.
The unit of measurement used to specify the time since acquisition instrument calibration value. Example: month.
propertyDescriptions.contributors_path: The name of the file containing the ORCID IDs for all contributors to this dataset. Example: contributors.csv.
propertyDescriptions.barcode_read: The sequencing read file contains the cell or capture spot barcode sequences. This information is essential when constructing sequencing libraries with a non-commercial kit, as it ensures that barcodes are correctly extracted during data processing. If the source material is not barcoded, this field should be marked as "Not applicable". Example: Read 1 (R1).
propertyDescriptions.barcode_size: The length of each cell or capture spot barcode in base pairs (bp). If the source material is not barcoded, enter "Not applicable". Example: 16.
propertyDescriptions.umi_read: Specifies which sequencing read file contains the Unique Molecular Identifier (UMI) barcode. If no UMI is used, enter "Not applicable". Example: Read 1 (R1).
propertyDescriptions.umi_size: The length of the Unique Molecular Identifier (UMI) in base pairs (bp). If no UMI is used, enter "Not applicable". Example: 8.
propertyDescriptions.assay_input_entity: The entity from which the analyte is captured. For example, in bulk sequencing, the source entity would be "tissue" while in single-cell sequencing, it would be "single cell". Example: single cell.
propertyDescriptions.number_of_input_cells_or_nuclei: The number of cells or nuclei that were input into the assay. This information is typically not available for assays performed on bulk tissue preparations, and therefore this field may be left blank. Example: 1000.
propertyDescriptions.library_adapter_sequence: The 5' and/or 3' adapter sequences used during library preparation to make the library compatible with the sequencing protocol and instrumentation. Adapter sequences should be provided as a comma-separated list of key-value pairs in the format: "adapter name: sequence". Example: Nextera Read 1: CTGTCTCTTATACACATCT.
propertyDescriptions.library_average_fragment_size: The average size of sequencing library fragments, measured in base pairs (bp), as estimated by gel electrophoresis, BioAnalyzer, or TapeStation. Example: 200.
propertyDescriptions.library_input_amount_value: The amount of cDNA, after amplification, that was used for library construction. Example: 60.
propertyDescriptions.library_input_amount_unit: The unit of measurement used to specify the library input amount value. Example: ng.
propertyDescriptions.library_output_amount_value: The total amount of library following the clean-up step after the final PCR amplification. To calculate, multiply the Qubit-measured concentration (ng/µl) by the elution volume (µl) obtained after the final clean-up. Example: 125.
propertyDescriptions.library_output_amount_unit: The unit of measurement used to specify the library output amount value. Example: ng.
propertyDescriptions.library_concentration_value: The concentration of the pooled library submitted for sequencing. Example: 2.5.
propertyDescriptions.library_concentration_unit: The unit of measurement used to specify the library concentration value. Example: ng/ul.
propertyDescriptions.library_layout: Indicates whether the sequencing library was prepared for single-end or paired-end sequencing. This information determines how reads are generated and aligned during data processing. Example: single-end.
propertyDescriptions.number_of_pcr_cycles_for_indexing: The number of PCR cycles used specifically to add sequencing adapters and amplify the library during the indexing step. This count does not include earlier cDNA amplification cycles, which are recorded separately under the "Number of iterations of cDNA amplification" field. Example: 8.
propertyDescriptions.library_preparation_kit: The reagent kit used to construct the sequencing library, including both the kit name and, if available, version and product number. If the library was prepared using a custom protocol, enter “Custom”. Example: 10X Genomics; Chromium Next GEM Single Cell 5' Kit v2, 16 rxns; PN 1000263.
propertyDescriptions.sample_indexing_kit: The reagent kit used to add index sequences to samples. Indexes enable multiplexing, allowing multiple libraries to be pooled and sequenced together on the same Illumina flow cell. Each indexing kit includes a set of compatible index sequences (often called "indexing sets") used to uniquely label a specific number of samples, depending on the kit’s design. If the library was prepared using a custom protocol, enter “Custom”. If no indexing was performed, enter "Not applicable". Example: 10X Genomics; Dual Index Kit TS, Set A; PN 1000251.
propertyDescriptions.sample_indexing_set: The specific sequencing barcode index set used, chosen from the sample indexing kit. For example, in the case of 10X, this might be "SI-GA-A1", whereas for Nextera, it could be "N505 - CTCCTTAC". Example: SI-GA-A1.
propertyDescriptions.is_technical_replicate: Indicates whether the sequencing reaction was run in replicate. If "Yes," the corresponding FASTQ files in the dataset should be merged for analysis. Example: Yes.
propertyDescriptions.expected_entity_capture_count: The number of cells, nuclei, or capture spots expected to be captured by the assay. Example: 14336.
propertyDescriptions.sequencing_reagent_kit: The reagent kit used to perform the sequencing run, including the platform, kit name, version, and product number when available. If the reagent kit was prepared using a custom protocol, enter “Custom”. Example: Illumina; NextSeq 500/550 Hi Output Kit 150 Cycles; v2.5; PN 20024907.
propertyDescriptions.sequencing_read_format: The number of sequencing cycles for each read and index in the sequencing run, typically reported as a comma-separated list in the order: Read 1, i7 index, i5 index, and Read 2. Example: 50,8,16,50.
propertyDescriptions.sequencing_batch_id: A lab-assigned identifier for the sequencing run, such as a chip ID, that enables users to determine which samples were processed together. To avoid ID conflicts across institutions, it is recommended to prefix the ID with the name of the sequencing center. Example: Broad_Chip1234.
propertyDescriptions.capture_batch_id: A lab-assigned identifier used to indicate which cells or nuclei were captured together in the same run. For example, in a 10X Genomics Chromium Controller workflow, this could be the chip ID used to trace datasets derived from a single capture event. This ID helps users identify samples processed together on the same device. To avoid conflicts across institutions, it is recommended to prefix the ID with the name of the sequencing center. Example: Broad_Batch1234.
propertyDescriptions.preparation_instrument_vendor: The company that manufactures the instrument used to prepare the sample (e.g., for staining or other processing steps) prior to the assay. If the instrument was custom-built or developed internally, enter "In-House". If no sample preparation occurred, enter "Not applicable". Example: 10X Genomics.
propertyDescriptions.preparation_instrument_model: The specific model of the instrument used for sample preparation, such as staining. Manufacturers may offer multiple models with varying features or sensitivities, which can influence how the sample is processed and how the resulting data is interpreted. If no sample preparation occurred, enter "Not applicable". Example: Chromium X.
propertyDescriptions.amount_of_input_analyte_value: The amount of RNA or DNA input into the assay, typically measured using instruments such as a Qubit, BioAnalyzer, or TapeStation. In most single-cell or single-nucleus assays, this value is usually not available, and therfore this field may be left blank. Example: 500.
propertyDescriptions.number_of_iterations_of_cdna_amplificati: The number of amplification cycles applied to cDNA prior to library construction. This is typically the number of PCR cycles used. For protocols using linear amplification methods (e.g., aRNA), this refers to the number of amplification rounds performed. Example: 3.
propertyDescriptions.preparation_instrument_kit: The reagent kit used in conjunction with the preparation instrument for sample processing (e.g., staining or labeling). If the reagent kit was prepared using a custom protocol, enter “Custom”. Example: 10X Genomics; Chromium Next GEM Chip G Single Cell Kit, 48 rxns; PN 1000120.
propertyDescriptions.preparation_protocol_doi: The DOI for the protocols.io page that details the assay or the procedures used for sample procurement and preparation. For example, in the case of an imaging assay, the protocol may start with tissue section staining and end with the generation of an OME-TIFF file. The documented protocol should also include any image processing steps involved in producing the final OME-TIFF. Example: https://dx.doi.org/10.17504/protocols.io.eq2lyno9qvx9/v1.
propertyDescriptions.is_targeted: Indicates whether a specific molecule or set of molecules is targeted for detection or measurement by the assay. Example: Yes.
propertyDescriptions.barcode_offset: The position within a sequencing read where a barcode sequence begins. In sequencing libraries, barcodes—short DNA sequences used to tag individual cells or molecules—are often arranged in a pattern where each barcode is separated by a constant sequence of known length. These constant sequences create predictable spacing between barcodes, known as offsets. For example, if barcodes are 8 base pairs (bp) long and separated by 30 bp constant regions, the barcodes might start at positions 0, 38, and 76 within the read. If the source material is not barcoded, this field should be marked as "Not applicable". Example: 0,38,76.
propertyDescriptions.umi_offset: The position within a sequencing read where the Unique Molecular Identifier (UMI) sequence begins. UMIs are short, random nucleotide sequences added to DNA or RNA fragments during library preparation to uniquely tag each original molecule. If no UMI is used, enter "Not applicable". Example: 16.
propertyDescriptions.probe_hybridization_time_value: The duration for which the oligo-conjugated RNA or oligo-conjugated antibody probes were hybridized with the sample. Example: 30.
propertyDescriptions.probe_hybridization_time_unit: The unit of measurement for the probe hybridization time value. If the hybridization time is not specified, this field may be left blank. Example: minute.
propertyDescriptions.oligo_probe_panel: The oligo probe panel used to target genes and/or proteins. If there is a core panel along with add-on modules, the core panel should be selected in this field. Any additional panels utilized should be documented in the "additional_panels_used.csv" file, which must be uploaded alongside the dataset. Example: 10x Genomics; Visium Human Transcriptome Probe Kit-Small; PN 1000363.
propertyDescriptions.is_custom_probes_used: Indicates whether custom RNA or antibody probes were utilized in the assay. If custom probes were employed, they should be documented in the "custom_probe_set.csv" file. Example: No.
propertyDescriptions.dataset_type: The specific type of dataset being produced. Default: RNAseq (with probes).
propertyDescriptions.amount_of_input_analyte_unit: The unit of measurement used to specify the amount of input analyte value. If no input amount, this field may be left blank. Example: ng.
propertyDescriptions.parent_sample_id: The unique identifier for the sample (such as a block, section, or suspension) used to perform the assay. For instance, in an RNAseq assay, the parent sample would be the suspension, while in imaging assays, it would be the tissue section. If the assay is derived from multiple parent samples, this field should contain a comma-separated list of identifiers. Identifiers may also include URLs or DOIs that point to the sample resources. Example: 10.1016/j.jchf.2022.08.010.

If no sample preparation occurred, enter "Not applicable". Example: Chromium X.

amount_of_input_analyte_value.title: amount_of_input_analyte_value field schema
amount_of_input_analyte_value.description: amount_of_input_analyte_value field schema generated by the CEDAR Template Editor 2.6.19
amount_of_input_analyte_value.schema:name: amount_of_input_analyte_value
amount_of_input_analyte_value.schema:description: The amount of RNA or DNA input into the assay, typically measured using instruments such as a Qubit, BioAnalyzer, or TapeStation. In most single-cell or single-nucleus assays, this value is usually not available, and therfore this field may be left blank. Example: 500.

number_of_iterations_of_cdna_amplificati.title: Untitled field schema
number_of_iterations_of_cdna_amplificati.description: Untitled field schema generated by the CEDAR Template Editor 2.6.19
number_of_iterations_of_cdna_amplificati.schema:name: number_of_iterations_of_cdna_amplification
number_of_iterations_of_cdna_amplificati.schema:description: The number of amplification cycles applied to cDNA prior to library construction. This is typically the number of PCR cycles used. For protocols using linear amplification methods (e.g., aRNA), this refers to the number of amplification rounds performed. Example: 3.
number_of_iterations_of_cdna_amplificati.skos:prefLabel: Number of iterations of cDNA amplification

preparation_instrument_kit.title: preparation_instrument_kit field schema
preparation_instrument_kit.description: preparation_instrument_kit field schema generated by the CEDAR Template Editor 2.6.19
preparation_instrument_kit.schema:name: preparation_instrument_kit
preparation_instrument_kit.schema:description: The reagent kit used in conjunction with the preparation instrument for sample processing (e.g., staining or labeling). If the reagent kit was prepared using a custom protocol, enter “Custom”. Example: 10X Genomics; Chromium Next GEM Chip G Single Cell Kit, 48 rxns; PN 1000120.

preparation_protocol_doi.title: Untitled field schema
preparation_protocol_doi.description: Untitled field schema generated by the CEDAR Template Editor 2.6.19
preparation_protocol_doi.schema:name: preparation_protocol_doi
preparation_protocol_doi.schema:description: The DOI for the protocols.io page that details the assay or the procedures used for sample procurement and preparation. For example, in the case of an imaging assay, the protocol may start with tissue section staining and end with the generation of an OME-TIFF file. The documented protocol should also include any image processing steps involved in producing the final OME-TIFF. Example: https://dx.doi.org/10.17504/protocols.io.eq2lyno9qvx9/v1.

is_targeted.title: Untitled field schema
is_targeted.description: Untitled field schema generated by the CEDAR Template Editor 2.6.19
is_targeted.schema:name: is_targeted
is_targeted.schema:description: Indicates whether a specific molecule or set of molecules is targeted for detection or measurement by the assay. Example: Yes.

barcode_offset.title: Untitled field schema
barcode_offset.description: Untitled field schema generated by the CEDAR Template Editor 2.6.19
barcode_offset.schema:name: barcode_offset
barcode_offset.schema:description: The position within a sequencing read where a barcode sequence begins. In sequencing libraries, barcodes—short DNA sequences used to tag individual cells or molecules—are often arranged in a pattern where each barcode is separated by a constant sequence of known length. These constant sequences create predictable spacing between barcodes, known as offsets. For example, if barcodes are 8 base pairs (bp) long and separated by 30 bp constant regions, the barcodes might start at positions 0, 38, and 76 within the read. If the source material is not barcoded, this field should be marked as "Not applicable". Example: 0,38,76.

umi_offset.title: Untitled field schema
umi_offset.description: Untitled field schema generated by the CEDAR Template Editor 2.6.44
umi_offset.schema:name: umi_offset
umi_offset.schema:description: The position within a sequencing read where the Unique Molecular Identifier (UMI) sequence begins. UMIs are short, random nucleotide sequences added to DNA or RNA fragments during library preparation to uniquely tag each original molecule. If no UMI is used, enter "Not applicable". Example: 16.

probe_hybridization_time_value.title: Untitled field schema
probe_hybridization_time_value.description: Untitled field schema generated by the CEDAR Template Editor 2.6.44
probe_hybridization_time_value.schema:name: probe_hybridization_time_value
probe_hybridization_time_value.schema:description: The duration for which the oligo-conjugated RNA or oligo-conjugated antibody probes were hybridized with the sample. Example: 30.

probe_hybridization_time_unit.title: probe_hybridization_time_unit field schema
probe_hybridization_time_unit.description: probe_hybridization_time_unit field schema generated by the CEDAR Template Editor 2.6.44
probe_hybridization_time_unit.schema:name: probe_hybridization_time_unit
probe_hybridization_time_unit.schema:description: The unit of measurement for the probe hybridization time value. If the hybridization time is not specified, this field may be left blank. Example: minute.

oligo_probe_panel.title: oligo_probe_panel field schema
oligo_probe_panel.description: oligo_probe_panel field schema generated by the CEDAR Template Editor 2.6.44
oligo_probe_panel.schema:name: oligo_probe_panel
oligo_probe_panel.schema:description: The oligo probe panel used to target genes and/or proteins. If there is a core panel along with add-on modules, the core panel should be selected in this field. Any additional panels utilized should be documented in the "additional_panels_used.csv" file, which must be uploaded alongside the dataset. Example: 10x Genomics; Visium Human Transcriptome Probe Kit-Small; PN 1000363.

is_custom_probes_used.title: Untitled field schema
is_custom_probes_used.description: Untitled field schema generated by the CEDAR Template Editor 2.6.44
is_custom_probes_used.schema:name: is_custom_probes_used
is_custom_probes_used.schema:description: Indicates whether custom RNA or antibody probes were utilized in the assay. If custom probes were employed, they should be documented in the "custom_probe_set.csv" file. Example: No.

dataset_type.title: dataset_type field schema
dataset_type.description: dataset_type field schema generated by the CEDAR Template Editor 2.6.19
dataset_type.schema:name: dataset_type
dataset_type.schema:description: The specific type of dataset being produced. Default: RNAseq (with probes).

amount_of_input_analyte_unit.title: amount_of_input_analyte_unit field schema
amount_of_input_analyte_unit.description: amount_of_input_analyte_unit field schema generated by the CEDAR Template Editor 2.6.19
amount_of_input_analyte_unit.schema:name: amount_of_input_analyte_unit
amount_of_input_analyte_unit.schema:description: The unit of measurement used to specify the amount of input analyte value. If no input amount, this field may be left blank. Example: ng.

parent_sample_id.title: Untitled field schema
parent_sample_id.description: Untitled field schema generated by the CEDAR Template Editor 2.6.19
parent_sample_id.schema:name: parent_sample_id
parent_sample_id.schema:description: The unique identifier for the sample (such as a block, section, or suspension) used to perform the assay. For instance, in an RNAseq assay, the parent sample would be the suspension, while in imaging assays, it would be the tissue section. If the assay is derived from multiple parent samples, this field should contain a comma-separated list of identifiers. Identifiers may also include URLs or DOIs that point to the sample resources. Example: 10.1016/j.jchf.2022.08.010.

about.title: about field schema
about.description: about field schema generated by the CEDAR Template Editor 2.7.1

_ui._content:
About this metadata template

This template provides metadata fields for datasets generated by RNAseq (with probes), in alignment with FAIR data principles to promote data sharing and reuse. Structured metadata enhances the discoverability, accessibility, interoperability, and reproducibility of biomedical research data.

Developed through community efforts within the HuBMAP and SenNet consortia, the template leverages the CEDAR Workbench platform for streamlined metadata authoring and management. These efforts contribute to enabling broad, consistent data sharing across the research community in accordance with NIH data sharing policies.

For assistance, please visit the HuBMAP Contact page or the SenNet Contact page.

Funding: This work was supported in part by IEC-HuBMAP (NIH Award OT2OD033759), IEC-SenNet (NIH Award xx), Penn-DCWG (NIH Grant U54HD104392), and Stanford-CEDAR (NIH Grant U54AI117925).

Citation: Use the following reference to cite the metadata specification: xx

about.schema:name: about

acknowledgement.title: acknowledgement field schema
acknowledgement.description: acknowledgement field schema generated by the CEDAR Template Editor 2.7.1

_valueConstraints.defaultValue: This schema provides a community standard for describing datasets generated by RNAseq (with probes) to promote FAIR data sharing across research communities. Developed by HuBMAP and SenNet using the CEDAR Workbench. Funding: IEC-HuBMAP (NIH Award OT2OD033759), IEC-SenNet (NIH Award xx), Penn-DCWG (NIH Grant U54HD104392), Stanford-CEDAR (NIH Grant U54AI117925).

acknowledgement.schema:name: acknowledgement

schema:name: RNAseq (with probes) Dataset
